ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Experience from 15 companies on standard rated lives only from the period January, 1991 to January, 2001. Data excludes the first two years of policy duration. Data roughly represents 57% of the in force lives however the remaining 43% of lives in force included a large proportion of data which might not be relevant to this survey e.g. critical illness policies. Insufficient data was received to complete an analysis by product type. Non-medical and medically underwritten policies combined as only 15% of the total lives are medical cases. For infant ages, data from "Demographic Trends in Hong Kong 1981 – 1996" by the Census and Statistics Department Hong Kong were relied upon. Methodology: The crude death rates were graduated using natural cubic splines with variable knots for the age range 2 to 70 years for both genders. The advantage of this method is that through varying the number and position of the knots of the cubic spline it is possible to steer the trade-off between fit and smoothness of the graduated qx. By definition of the cubic splines the resulting curve is smooth to the second order. For the sparse datasets at the high ages or the rapid change of mortality from age 0 to 2 the spline graduation delivered non-satisfactory results. Hence for ages above 70, the mortality rates were graduated using Makeham-type functions. there is no explicit margin for conservatism built into these tables. Data Transcription Errors: None.
